Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Microscope-based Technology For Automatic Brain Cell Counts Using Unbiased Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is in automating the process of unbiased stereology, the state-of-the-method used in the life sciences for counting stained cells on tissue sections. Unbiased stereology allows neuroscientists to accurately analyze the size and number of brain cells, which are altered in many neurological disorders and mental illnesses. For reasons that are currently unknown, Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease and Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis are all associated with a progressive loss of brain cells. In contrast, children with autism are born with too many brain cells, which leads to life-long problems in processing complex streams of information. Stereology plays an important role in investigating many conditions affecting the brain and assessing the efficacy and safety of possible treatments. Though the proposed technology will initially target research studies to understand and treat all neurological conditions, it can be useful for automatic assessments of cells in all tissues, including cancer screening and diagnosis from biopsies.


The proposed project will develop and optimize an algorithm to help brain scientists identify causes and treatments for neurological disease and mental illness. The proposed technology will use deep learning (artificial intelligence) systems to automatically recognize, count and size brain cells on tissue sections. An important use of this technology will be to analyze brains and nerve tissue from mice and rats treated to show similar neurological diseases as those found in humans. These animal models provide a powerful tool for testing treatments to cure brain disease in humans. Currently stereology studies of tissues from these animals require a trained technician to sit before a computer screen making tedious manual counts of hundreds and thousands of microscopic cells. This outdated approach fails to take advantage of powerful deep learning methods proposed for the proposed software that could complete these tasks 10 times faster and with fewer errors and human biases. Therefore, the proposed technology will use deep learning technology to accelerate basic research and drug development in the U.S., thereby establishing a long-term economic engine and bringing significant benefits to society through scientific breakthroughs and medical discoveries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Deep learning is an example of machine learning, or more broadly, artificial intelligence (AI), in which a computerized system (neural network) learns to perform tasks previously done by people. AI has improved society in many ways -- automatic reading of zip codes, voice recognition by smart phones and predicting the effects of new drugs on diseases.  Deep learning follows a similar approach to the way humans learn: repetition (viewing images) then trial, error and reinforcement to accurately perform a task. With training, a deep learning program can quickly equal the performance of the people who trained them. 

Deep learning is especially effective for tasks that are tedious and boring. For example, cell counting is done on a daily basis by over 350,000 bioscientists worldwide who study human diseases. A basic concept in biology is that all living organisms are composed of cells. Because the vast majority of cells lack color, they must first be stained with dyes in order to see them. Since the cells are too small to be seen by the naked eye, cell counts must be done under the microscope. Using current state-of-the-art methods, the magnified images of stained cells are counted by a trained human clicking over cells one at a time. Though time-consuming, laborious and costly, this approach does give accurate results. However, our automatic approach showed that deep learning can achieve the same results in a small fraction of the time and with little effort from humans.

We showed our deep learning approach can automatically count two types of stained brain cells (neurons, neuroglial cells). As mentioned above, the conventional method for counting cells requires a user to manually click on cells. The results are based on the number of clicks and do not require saving the images of counted cells, which means no record is created therefore there is no way to monitor accuracy. The first contribution of our deep learning approach is the images of all counted cells are saved, thereby creating a permanent record of the cells counted and a way to review the results for mistakes. Second, we created a quality control battery for testing and comparing the accuracy of different methods, such as manual counts by a trained human compared to automatic counts by a deep learning network. For instance, our quality control battery showed our deep learning approach has the same accuracy but is more precise (> 99% reproducibility) and more than 5 times faster than manual clicks by a trained human. Because our approach did the work more than 5x faster, it means that our approach can complete 5 times more work with the same accuracy as a trained human technician. One drawback to deep learning is the requirement for a bioscience expert to train the neural network by marking (clicking) on hundreds of stained cells in microscopic images. This process is time-consuming and requires expertise from bioscience experts who are not typically available to computer scientists. Our third contribution is we addressed this problem by automating the cell marking process. By eliminating the need for bioscience experts to verify (manually mark the correct cells), our automatic cell marking approach reduces the time, effort and cost to make automatic cell counts.

A major advantage of our deep learning approach is it frees highly trained technicians to do high-tech tasks while our deep learning software counts cells, a task that is mundane and subject to human bias and counting errors. We expect our automatic cell counting approach, also known as Fully Automatic Stereology Technology (FAST), to make significant impacts in several areas of science and medicine. By accelerating the pace of reliable research studies, automatic cell counts can help 1) identify drugs that are safe and effective; 2) understand how genetic manipulations lead to cellular changes; and, 3) rapidly assess whether compounds are toxic to cells. Other contributions will be to develop drugs to block tissue damage from cell inflammation, provide more accurate screening of tissue specimens for the presence of malignant cells, and identify the best methods for blocking the neuron loss in Alzheimer's disease.

This project results have been widely disseminated through high-profile peer-reviewed journal publications, workshops, conference presentations, and other venues including web portals available to the entire scientific community. Since machine learning and automatic cell counts have broad applications to many bioscience and medical disciplines, it is expected that our approach will accelerate scientific breakthroughs, medical discoveries and bring broad economic benefits to society.
